item.title: Enabling OSS Innovation in Universities
item.description: Society has reached a tipping point in terms of the global use of open source. The benefits of open source development and research is widely recognized and this is underscored by the recent introduction of policies across public and private institutions and governments.

item.title: Collaborating for Open Source Innovation
item.description: At the recent CURIOSS ‘Open Source Innovation in Universities event’, Cindy Chepanoske (Director of Technology Licensing at the Center for Technology Transfer and Enterprise Creation, Carnegie Mellon University); Jacob Green, (Founder of CURIOSS); Joe Doyle (IP Manager at Enterprise Ireland); John Whelan (ICT Research Commercialization Manager, Open Source Program Office, Trinity College Dublin); and Lucie Smolka (CEO, Open Cities) discussed collaboration in the context of open source innovation.

item.title: Open Source Policy Trends in Europe
item.description: The fact that open source was once considered a subversive, fringe movement seems inconceivable today. Having powered innovation for decades while staying largely outside the spotlight, open source is now in approximately 92% of software across all sectors and around the world.

item.title: Commercial Open Source Software
item.description: Open source software (OSS) is often available at no cost. However, in recent years, we have seen a significant number of high-growth companies emerge with business models that incorporate OSS.

item.description: Defining ‘Open Science’ UNESCO states open science is: “… An inclusive construct that combines various movements and practices aiming to make multilingual scientific knowledge openly available, accessible and reusable for everyone.

item.description: CURIOSS Policy, Governments & Agencies Working Group CURIOSS was honored to host a very special global event on Institutionalizing Open Source and building new cooperation infrastructure.

item.title: All the Boats Must Rise
item.description: In 20+ years of helping all sorts of organizations and people understand and participate in Open Source, the most difficult concept for learners is what I call the “All Boats Must Rise” concept.
